member.name: P:Infragistics.Controls.Scheduler.SchedulerView.ViewSplitOrientation
member.summary: Returns/sets the which determines whether the primary and secondary views are split vertically or horizontally.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Controls.Scheduler.SchedulerView.ViewSplitOrientationMode
member.summary: Returns/sets the which determines whether the orientation of the split between views is changed automatically based on control aspect ratio changes or manually by the developer.
member.remarks:
When this property is set to (the default), the control will automatically set the to a value that makes best use of the control's current aspect ratio. Specifically, if the control's width is greater than the control's height then the will be automatically set to so that the views are arranged side by side to make the best use of the control's available width. Similarly, if the control's height is greater than the control's width then the will be automatically set to so that the views are arranged one above the other to make the best use of the control's available height.
When this property is set to the control will not automatically set the - in this case the developer is responsible for setting the property to a value that makes sense for the application.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Controls.Scheduler.SchedulerView.EnsureDayVisibleInAgendaView(System.DateTime,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Ensures that the specified date is visible in the , and if not scrolls the day into view.
member.remarks: If an has not been selected as a primary or secondary view mode (see the and properties) calling this method has no effect and the call will return false.
member.param: The date that should be scrolled into view. The date must fall within the and unless is set to .
True to perform an animated scroll, false to perform an immediate scroll.
True to make sure the specified date is visible and scroll the date to the top of the visible area, false to simply make sure the specified date is visible.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Controls.Scheduler.SchedulerView.EnsureDayVisibleInMonthView(System.DateTime,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Ensures that the day represented by the specified date is visible in the , and if not scrolls the date into view.
member.remarks: If the control's property is not set to calling this method has no effect and the call will return false.
member.param: The date representing the day that should be scrolled into view. The date must fall between the control's Min and Max dates.
True to perform an animated scroll, false to perform an immediate scroll.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Controls.Scheduler.SchedulerView.EnsureMonthVisibleInMonthView(System.DateTime,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Ensures that the month containing the specified date is visible in the , and if not scrolls the month into view.
member.remarks: If the control's property is not set to calling this method has no effect and the call will return false.
member.param: The date whose containing month should be scrolled into view. The date must fall between the control's Min and Max dates.
True to perform an animated scroll, false to perform an immediate scroll.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Controls.Scheduler.SchedulerView.ExportVisualModel
member.summary: Returns the exported as a instance for the main view. If the control is displaying more than one view (e.g., MonthView plus AgendaView), and you want the export data for the secondary view, call the overload that takes a parameter.
member.returns: The VisualModel exported as a instance.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Controls.Scheduler.SchedulerView.Refresh
member.summary: Invalidates the control's view and refreshes its layout visual contents.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Controls.Scheduler.SchedulerView.SuspendRefreshAndPerformAction(System.Action)
member.summary: This method performs the specified action after temporarily suspending the refresh of the control layout. Once the action is completed, the control's layout is refreshed and and any changes made inside the action will be reflected in the control's UI. Use this method to improve performance when you need to set multiple properties that affect the control's layout.
member.param: The Action to perform while the control's refresh is suspended.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Controls.Scheduler.AppointmentPropertyMapping
member.summary: Encapsulates a property mapping for an .

remarks.p: The class provides the ability to specify an item source from which data objects which represent appointments can be obtained.
In cases where the name or data type of the data object property does not match the name or data type of the corresponding appointment property, a mapping can be used to resolve the name and/or type.
In cases where the name or data type of the data object property does not match the name or data type of the corresponding appointment property, a mapping can be used to resolve the name and/or type.
For example, assume there exists a data object property named 'StartDate', which is the property from which the appointment's Start property value is obtained.

To create a mapping between these two properties, a new AppointmentPropertyMapping object is created with a Property value of Start, and a DataObjectPropertyName of 'StartDate', i.e., the actual name of the data object property.

This AppointmentPropertyMapping object is then added to the ScheduleListDataSource's AppointmentPropertyMappings collection; this signifies to the data source that the value the Appointment's Start property is to be obtained/assigned from/to a property named 'StartDate' on the data object.

A property mapping can also be used to perform bi-directional conversions between an appointment property and the corresponding data object property using the ConvertCallback AND ConvertBackCallback properties. These properties accept a delegate which is invoked whenever data is transferred between the appointment and it's underlying data object, providing the ability to change the value.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Controls.Scheduler.ScheduleDataSource
member.summary: Abstract base class for a data source which provides and data.

remarks.p: ScheduleDataSource provides the ability to bind the to a source of data from which and objects can be created, updated, and deleted.
Use the method to obtain a subset of objects which lie in a specific date range.
To update an existing object, call the method to begin the edit session, and the method to commit changes made to the object.
Similarly, a new Appointment can be created by calling the method, followed by a call to EndEdit to commit the changes.
To delete an existing Appointment, use the method.

Because the ScheduleDataSource class supports asynchronous interaction with a data source, the create/read/update/delete related methods return an object from which the data can be obtained synchronously or asynchronously, depending on the derived class implementation.
The class provides a concrete implementation of ScheduleDataSource, for synchronous access to a locally stored data source. See documentation of that class for details.

Delegate which is called if an error occurs.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Controls.Scheduler.ScheduleDataSource.CreateAppointment
member.summary: When overridden in a derived class, creates a new .
member.returns: A reference to the new or null if the operation fails.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Controls.Scheduler.ScheduleDataSource.CreateAppointment(System.Action{Infragistics.Scheduler.Data.DataError})
member.summary: When overridden in a derived class, creates a new .
member.param: Delegate which is called if an error occurs.
member.returns: A reference to the new or null if the operation fails. To receive detailed information about the reson the operation failed, a delegate must be assigned to the parameter.

remarks.p: The CreateAppointment method returns a new, uninitialized instance. This appointment is not associated with the data source until the method is called; as such, it will not appear in activity queries or in the user interface of an attached .
Note that the method must be called to commit the creation of the new appointment.

Also note that the underlying item source for appointment data must support creation of new objects. Typically this requires that the object expose a parameterless constructor. Derived classes may provide alternative means through which a new data object instance can be created.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Controls.Scheduler.ScheduleDataSource.DeleteAppointment(Infragistics.Scheduler.Appointment)
member.summary: When overridden in a derived class, deletes the specified .
member.param: The appointment to be deleted.
member.returns: An instance which contains the result of the operation.

remarks.p: The DeleteAppointment method removes an existing instance, and causes it to become disassociated from the data source. After a successful deletion, the Appointment no longer appears in activity queries or in the user interface.
Note that the underlying item source for appointment data must support removal of items.

member.summary: Commits changes made to an during an edit mode session initiated by the or methods.
member.param: The being edited.
True to force exiting of edit mode.
member.returns: An instance containing the result of the operation.

member.summary: Returns an enumerable list of the resources associated with this data source.

remarks.p: A provides the ability to group data; activity queries can filter by a resource to limit the query result so that only appointments associated with a given resource are returned.

The manner in which resources are associated with the data source is dependent on the derived class implementation; for example, exposes a property through which an item source for the resource data can be defined.

If true the query terminates as soon as it encounters activity in the given range. Use this if you are not interested in which dates have activity, only whether each date in the specified range contains any activity at all.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Controls.Scheduler.ScheduleListDataSource
member.summary: -derived class for use with lists of objects that provide data from which appointments and resources can be created.

remarks.p: The ScheduleListDataSource class provides the ability to bind a list of "plain old CLR objects" (commonly referred to as a "POCOs"), which provide and data. An existing class can be used to represent an appointment or a resource, provided that the class exposes properties of the required type. If the names of these properties are the same as the corresponding appointment/resource property, these properties are automatically bound to their respective appointment/resource properties; if the names are different, property mapping support is provided through the and collections.

The property accepts any value which implements the IEnumerable interface. However, with a simple IEnumerable implementation, certain functionality is not supported, most notably creation of new appointments, and deletion of existing ones. External modifications to the item source are not reflected by the ScheduleListDataSource class, since the IEnumerable interface does not provide any change notification mechanism.

With an item source which implements the IList interface, creation and deletion of appointments through the ScheduleListDataSource API is supported, but external changes to the item source are, as with an IEnumerable implementation, not reflected by the ScheduleListDataSource, again due to the lack of a change notification mechanism. Note that the List<T> class falls into this category as well.

An item source which implements the IList and INotifyCollectionChanged interfaces provides the most functionality, as content change methods as well as notification methods exist. In this case, creation and deletion is supported both through the ScheduleListDataSource API and via external changes to the collection. When possible, it is best to use the ObservableCollection<T> class, which supports both content change and notification mechanisms.

Another requirement for the ability to create new appointments is a public parameterless constructor exposed by the underlying data object class. If the class does not expose a public parameterless constructor, the property can be used to provide a factory method which is called when a new Appointment object is created. Without a parameterless constructor or a factory method, addition of new appointments is not supported, regardless of whether the item source supports content changes.

The property works the same as AppointmentItemsSource, although because adding/removing resources is not supported through the user interface, it is not as important to use a list type which supports creation and deletion.

Note that the "POCO" object which provides the backing store for an appointment or resource must implement the INotifyPropertyChanged interface in order to support external changes made to that object. Without such a property change notification mechanism, ScheduleListDataSource cannot react to changes made to property values, and as such will not be able to keep the corresponding properties of the appointment or resource object synchronized. Changes made to property values of the Appointment and ScheduleResource class through the API, however, are immediately reflected by ScheduleListDataSource, and are immediately propagated back to the underlying data object as well.
The following table summarizes the functionality which is available under each usage scenario:

tr.td: Provides only basic functionality. An appointment/resource is created for each item in the list, but adding new items and removing existing ones is not supported.
Provides the ability to add/remove appointments/resources, but only through the API.
Provides the ability to add/remove appointments/resources through external changes made to the item source.

Addition and removal of appointments/resources is supported both through the API as well as external changes made to the item source. For best results, the ObservableCollection<T> class is recommended as this class implements both interfaces.

If implemented on the underlying data object class (i.e., "POCO"), external changes made to properties of the object are immediately synchronized with the corresponding appointment/resource object. Note that changes made through appointment/resource properties are always propagated back to the underlying data object, so an INotifyPropertyChanged implementation is unnecessary in that scenario.

member.name: M:Infragistics.Controls.Scheduler.ScheduleListDataSource.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new instance.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Controls.Scheduler.ScheduleListDataSource.AppointmentItemsSource
member.summary: Returns or sets the list of data objects from which appointments are created.

remarks.p: While any IEnumerable implementation can serve as a valid items source, some functionality may not be available depending on the implementation.

For example, if the specified item source does not implement the IList interface, appointments cannot be added or removed, since the IEnumerable interface alone does not provide a way to modify the contents of the underlying list.
Furthermore, the IList implementation must allow for content modification, i.e., it's IsFixedSize and IsReadOnly properties must return true.

Also note that because the IList interface does not provide support for content modification notifications, external changes to the item source will not be recognized by the data source, resulting in synchronization issues.

If the application requires that external changes to the item source be synchronized with the data source, it is necessary to use a class which implements the INotifyCollectionChanged interface, such as ObservableCollection<T>.

In cases where the names or types of the data object properties which are bound to appointment properties are disparate, use the collection to provide a mapping between the data object and appointment.

When an element in the item source cannot yield successful creation of an appointment object, the event occurs, providing a detailed description of the direct cause of the rejection. This event can be useful during debugging sessions.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Controls.Scheduler.ScheduleListDataSource.AppointmentPropertyMappings
member.summary: Returns a collection which enables the developer to map an property to a property of the underlying data object which has a different name.

remarks.p: In cases where the names of the properties on the underlying data object are all the same as that of the schedule object properties to which they are bound, a mapping can be automatically assumed to exist. In this case, no explicit mappings are necessary.

In the case where a property of the underlying data object has the same name as a schedule object property, but the developer does not want a mapping to exist, add an with a null value for the property.

In cases where the data type of the bound property does not match that of the corresponding schedule object property, conversion is attempted, but is limited by the functionality provided by the Convert class. For example, an appointment's Start property can be mapped to a field of type string (assuming the data contained therein is a valid string representation of a date/time). Similarly, the Id property can be mapped to a field of type integer, since the numeric value can be converted to a string.

In cases where the value of the bound property is not convertible to that of the schedule object property, the and
methods can be used to convert data bi-directionally.
The following properties require mappings:

member.name: P:Infragistics.Controls.Scheduler.ScheduleListDataSource.CreateAppointmentDataObjectCallback
member.summary: Returns or sets a delegate which is called to create a data object for a newly created .

remarks.p: In cases where it is not possible to determine the type of the items contained within the , a new instance of that type cannot be automatically created using reflection. This is also the case for a type which does not publicly expose a parameterless constructor.
This property makes it possible for the developer to receive a callback at the time of instance creation, thereby providing a way for a corresponding data object to be created.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Controls.Scheduler.ScheduleListDataSource.HandleAppointmentItemsPropertyChanged
member.summary: Determines whether the INotifyPropertyChanged.PropertyChanged event is handled for data objects.

remarks.p: In order to receive a notification when a property of an Appointment's underlying data object changes value, the data source will register as a listener of the data object's INotifyPropertyChanged.PropertyChanged event. This enables the corresponding object to react to external changes and synchronize it's own property values accordingly.
In cases where the contains a relatively large number of items, this can affect performance and/or memory consumption adversely.
This property provides a way for the developer to switch this behavior off, thus signaling to the data source that the PropertyChanged event should not be handled.
This property is only applicable when the underlying data object implements the INotifycPropertyChanged interface.

Also note that the data source exposes a method, which routes through the same logic as the handler for the data object's PropertyChanged event. Call this method directly to simulate the PropertyChanged event for the specified appointment data object, thus achieving the same result as handling the PropertyChanged event.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Controls.Scheduler.ScheduleListDataSource.ResourceItemsSource
member.summary: Returns or sets the list of data objects from which appointments are created.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Controls.Scheduler.ScheduleListDataSource.ResourcePropertyMappings
member.summary: Returns a collection which enables the developer to map a property to a property of the underlying data object which has a different name.

remarks.p: In cases where the names of the properties on the underlying data object are all the same as that of the schedule object properties to which they are bound, a mapping can be automatically assumed to exist. In this case, no explicit mappings are necessary.

In the case where a property of the underlying data object has the same name as a schedule object property, but the developer does not want a mapping to exist, add an with a null value for the property.

Note that in cases where the data type of the bound property does not match that of the schedule object property, the and
methods can be used to convert data bi-directionally.
The following properties require mappings:

member.name: M:Infragistics.Controls.Scheduler.ScheduleListDataSource.RaisePropertyChanged(System.Object,Infragistics.Scheduler.Data.AppointmentProperty)
member.summary: Notifies the data source of a change to a property value of the specified .
member.param: The data object whose property value has changed.
A constant identifying the property whose value has changed.

remarks.p: In cases where there are a relatively large number of data objects in the , performance may be adversely impacted by handling the PropertyChanged event via the data object's INotifyPropertyChanged interface. To avoid this, set the property to false.
Note that if the data source is created in this manner, the state of the corresponding object cannot be automatically synchronized with that of the underlying data object.

Use this method to manually send a property change notification for the affected data object and property value, thus ensuring that the state of the appointment object is synchronized with that of the underlying data object.

member.name: T:Infragistics.Controls.Scheduler.SchedulePropertyMapping
member.summary: Encapsulates a property mapping for a schedule object such as an or .

member.name: P:Infragistics.Controls.Scheduler.SchedulePropertyMapping.ConvertBackCallback
member.summary: Reference to a delegate which is invoked before the value of a schedule object property is assigned 'back' to the underlying data object's corresponding property, providing an opportunity to convert the value to the type expected by that property.

remarks.p: To bypass conversion, return the same value that was passed into this method. If null is returned, a value of null will be assigned to the underlying data object property, which will cause an exception to be thrown if null is not a valid value for that property.

member.name: P:Infragistics.Controls.Scheduler.SchedulePropertyMapping.ConvertCallback
member.summary: Reference to a delegate which is invoked before a value is assigned to a schedule object property, providing an opportunity to convert the value.

remarks.p: To bypass conversion, return the same value that was passed into this method. If null is returned, a value of null will be assigned to the schedule object property, which will cause an exception to be thrown if null is not a valid value for that property.
